frameDefinitions: An Entity (generally food) is exposed to a Heat_source whose Temperature may also be specified.
This frame pertains to noise verbs used to characterize motion.
An Entity changes from a Prior_state to a Post_state in a sequence that follows a pre-defined plan, expectation, or model of change.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer being aware (or not being aware) of the difference between two Phenomena, which may be expressed jointly or disjointly.
A Fire burns Fuel, resulting in damage and possibly complete destruction of the Fuel.
An Entity has a Temperature characterized by the target.
frameExamples: Bacon was <t>frying</t> in the pan, and a great heap of eggs already lay steaming on a plate.
Their offensive armament has <t>developed</t> from short range missiles to long-range ballistic weaponry in a relatively short period .
It is very difficult for people to visually <t>distinguish</t> between living and non-living things from such a great distance .
A fire that started on Saturday afternoon, the High Glade Fire - located on the Mendocino National Forest's Upper Lake Ranger District - continued to <t>burn</t> actively on Sunday.
The pan is already too <t>hot</t> to touch.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Entity</fen> (often a food item)  that absorbs heat.
The <fen>Container</fen> that holds the <fen>Entity</fen> that absorbs the heat.
This role identifies the object that directly supplies heat to the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the heat absorption takes place.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the heat application occurs.

The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that changes location.  In sentences containing a <fen>Cause</fen>, the <fen>Theme</fen> is typically the NP Object.  In other sentences, the <fen>Theme</fen> is normally the External Argument.
The <fen>Source</fen> is any expression which implies a definite starting-point of Motion.
The <fen>Path</fen> is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is any expression which tells where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the Motion.
This role identifies the general <fen>Area</fen> in which motion takes place, used particularly if the motion is understood as following a complex or non-linear path.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the motion event takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location of a more specific motion (which has <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, <fen>Goal</fen>, or <fen>Area</fen>).
The object that undergoes change.
The time at which the progress occurs.
The location where the Progress occurs.
The cognizer is the person (or other sentient being) who potentially determines that two Phenomena are distinct from each other. It is normally expressed as an External Argument:

The phenomena that are potentially judged to be different from one another can be expressed as separate constituents. When they are, one is typically expressed as an NP Object, and the other as a PP Complement headed by <ment>from</ment>:
See Phenomenon_1, above. The phenomenon expressed less prominently as a PP complement is called <fen>Phenomenon_2</fen>:
Both phenomena that are potentially judged to be different from one another can be expressed jointly by the same constituent:

This is a property that is potentially used by the Cognizer to distinguish one phenomenon from another. It is normally expressed as a PP headed by a preposition such as <ment>from</ment>, <ment>by</ment>, or <ment>on the basis of</ment>:

The total material currently involved in combustion, including both the parts of the <fen>Fuel</fen> currently undergoing chemical alteration and the partially ionized gas that results from this process.
The entity that is undergoing rapid chemical alteration leading to damage or destruction.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Fire</fen> is burning.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Fire</fen> is burning.
The <fen>Entity</fen> for which the temperature <fen>Attribute</fen> is under consideration.
The feature of an <fen>Entity</fen> which is under discussion.
A quantity or other characterization of the <fen>Entity</fen>'s state with respect to the temperature <fen>Attribute</fen>.
A modifier expressing  the deviation of the <fen>Temperature</fen> from the norm.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Entity</fen> is in the state of having  a particular <fen>Degree</fen> for the temperature <fen>Attribute</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Bacon</fex> frying in the pan and scenting the air
Five fat sausages were frying <fex>in the pan</fex>
Food was placed to sizzle <fex>on the barbecue </fex>.
<fex>Five minutes ago</fex>the eggs weren't boiling yet.
<fex>In the kitchen</fex> the meat sizzled in the oven and a big pan of potatoes stood on the hob
<fex>Pat</fex> crunched over the fresh snow.
The train rumbled <fex>out of the station</fex>.
The truck roared <fex>through the tunnel</fex>.
The plates clattered <fex>to the floor</fex>.
The fly buzzed <fex>about the room</fex>.
The train screeched into the station <fex>at half past seven</fex>
Advances <fex>in marketing techniques</fex> have since rendered it obsolete.
<fex>When</fex> did the X-wing progress beyond the drawing board?
<fex>The teacher</fex> couldn't distinguish one child from the other.
The teacher couldn't distinguish Pat from Kim.
The teacher couldn't distinguish Pat <fex>from Kim</fex>.
The teacher couldn't distinguish <fex>the twins</fex>.
The coach could distinguish the twins <fex>by their hair</fex>.
<fex>The soup</fex>'s too hot.
The skillet had a temperature <fex>of 230 F</fex>
